Award.AwardTitle: Utilization of Collagen Remodeling Pathways to Control Gene Delivery

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1159466/ Sullivan

Intellectual Merit: The overall objective of the proposed project is to develop DNA-linked collagen hydrogels whose remodeling by fibroblast cells will stimulate DNA release and efficient gene delivery. Ultimately, these novel scaffolds will be used to trigger robust (and low cost) in situ expression of growth factors (GFs) to enable healing of chronic wounds and other damaged tissues. In the proposed approach, collagen scaffolds will be modified with plasmid DNAs by newly linking DNA-binding peptides (DBPs) and collagen mimetic peptides (CMPs) with previously established capacities for gene transfer (DBPs) and collagen modification (CMPs). The proposed work will test the following hypotheses: (1) native collagen remodeling processes involving collagen degradation [by matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs)] and collagen endocytosis [by alpha2 beta1 integrins and caveolin-1] will trigger the release and endocytosis of collagen-linked DNA "polyplexes"; (2) collagen linkage will initiate DNA trafficking through efficient gene delivery routes involving caveolin-1. Completion of the proposed aims should provide fundamentally new strategies to understand and direct gene delivery, and in the long term, will foster new materials and therapeutic strategies in tissue repair.

Broader Impacts: Given the wealth of target GFs and the widespread use of collagen-based materials, the proposed studies will advance the use of collagen-mediated gene delivery not only in chronic wound repair, but also in multiple other applications such as implant functionalization and regenerative medicine. The proposed efforts are also designed to provide new research and career development opportunities, including industrial mentorship, for undergraduates, high school interns, and underrepresented groups, by building on existing undergraduate research and outreach infrastructure at UD, as well as on previous educational activities of Kiick and Sullivan.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was focused on the development of new strategies for gene therapy that could ultimately be used to enable improved healing of wounds or other injured tissues. Our strategy was to design a new type of ‘hydrogel’ material. Hydrogels are molecular networks that swell in water, such as the materials used in contact lenses and topical wound dressings. We specifically sought to design hydrogels that would mimic extracellular matrix (ECM), the protein network providing structural and biochemical support to human tissues. ECM is an essential non-cellular component in all tissues, and its physical/biochemical properties and interactions with cells define tissue three-dimensional structure, mechanical properties, and barrier function. Moreover, ECM binds to signaling proteins like growth factors and controls when and where these signaling proteins are released to cells to trigger wound repair. Many viruses have ‘coopted’ ECM to mediate infection: these viruses also bind to ECM leading to increased infectivity.

To design hydrogels that would mimic ECM to enable gene therapy, we synthesized molecules called collagen mimetic peptides, or CMPs, and we attached the CMPs to gene-encoding nanoparticles. We showed that the CMP-nanoparticles bound to simple, collagen-based ECM gels with high affinity. Furthermore, depending upon the sequence and number of CMPs that were attached to the nanoparticles, the affinity for collagen could be changed such that the particles would be retained for long periods of time in the gels (e.g. months) or released more quickly (e.g. over a few days). The DNA within the nanoparticles stayed intact, and active over a period of multiple weeks. We also showed that cells would grow on the nanoparticle-linked collagen, and these cells degraded the collagen using naturally-occurring proteases leading to the cell-mediated release of the nanoparticles. Moreover, when the cells released the nanoparticles, these nanoparticles entered the cells and the genes encoded by the nanoparticles were expressed (e.g. used to produce encoded proteins). CMP linkage provided a useful way to control when, where, and how long the gene expression occurred. When the encoded genes were growth factor genes, we showed that growth factor expression could be controlled to promote faster wound healing. These results demonstrate exciting potential for these new ECM inspired materials as novel wound dressings able to solve persistent problems with impaired healing in chronic wounds.

The broader educational impacts of our studies included new efforts to train high school students in biomaterials and engineering research through internships in the PIs’ laboratories. Furthermore, new topics inspired by this research were introduced into regular and study abroad courses at the University of Delaware, enabling expanded dissemination and impacts.


Last Modified: 10/29/2017
Modified by: Millicent O Sullivan

Our strategy was to design a new type of ?hydrogel? material. Hydrogels are molecular networks that swell in water, such as the materials used in contact lenses and topical wound dressings. ECM is an essential non-cellular component in all tissues, and its physical/biochemical properties and interactions with cells define tissue three-dimensional structure, mechanical properties, and barrier function. Moreover, ECM binds to signaling proteins like growth factors and controls when and where these signaling proteins are released to cells to trigger wound repair. Many viruses have ?coopted? ECM to mediate infection: these viruses also bind to ECM leading to increased infectivity. We showed that the CMP-nanoparticles bound to simple, collagen-based ECM gels with high affinity.
